head.headtext: Photographs, motion pictures, videotapes, and x-rays

para.paratext: There are two issues pertinent to a discussion of the admissibility of photographic evidence: the admissibility of various forms of photographic evidence and their relevancy in certain situations.

O.C.G.A. § 24-9-923 provides procedures, supplementary to other state statutes and law, for the admission of photographs, motion pictures, videotapes, and audiotapes when a person who could otherwise authenticate such evidence is unavailable. It provides:

Subject to any other valid objection, photographs, motion pictures, videotapes, and audio recordings shall be admissible in evidence when necessitated by the unavailability of a witness who can provide personal authentication and when the court determines, based on competent evidence presented to the court, that such items tend to show reliably the fact or facts for which the items are offered.
[1]
Under the statute, a witness is deemed to be “unavailable” if the authenticating witness:
Is exempted by ruling of the court on the ground of privilege from testifying concerning the subject matter of the authentication;
Persists in refusing to testify concerning the subject matter of the authentication despite an order of the court to do so;
Testifies to a lack of memory of the subject matter of the authentication;
Is unable to be present or to testify at the hearing because of death or then existing physical or mental illness or infirmity; or
Is absent from the hearing and the proponent of the authentication has been unable to procure the attendance of the authenticating witness by process or other reasonable means.

An authenticating witness is not unavailable as a witness if his or her exemption, refusal, claim of lack of memory, inability, or absence is due to the procurement or wrongdoing of the proponent of an authentication for the purpose of preventing the witness from attending or testifying.[
2]

Where photographs are properly admitted, an overhead projector may be used to display them to the jury.[
3]

Ga. Sup. Ct. R. 71 provides in part: “Where the admissibility of photographs is attacked, the originals or exact duplicates, to be furnished by appellant, shall be included in the transcript.”
Ga. Ct. of Appeals R. 21 provides for original evidence or exhibits to be transmitted to the appellate court on motion of a party explaining “the reason such original evidence or exhibits are necessary for the determination of the appeal.”

The identification requirements of O.C.G.A. § 24-9-901 apply to photographs.
O.C.G.A. § 24-10-1001(2) subjects photographs to the best evidence rule and defines them as “still photographs, X-ray films, video tapes, and motion pictures.”
There have been some interesting federal cases involving authentication of film taken by a bank camera during a robbery.[
4]

Authentication of photographs may take various forms and is a matter for the judge's discretion.[
5] The proffering party must show that the photograph is substantially a true representation of that which it purports to represent as it existed at the time at issue or at a later time if there has been no substantial change in conditions.[
6]

A verifying witness does not have to be the photographer or have seen the photographer take the photograph, but should be able to state that the photograph represents that which it purports to represent.[
7] For example, a videotape can be authenticated by the operator of the machine that produced it or someone who personally witnessed the event recorded and testifies that the videotape accurately portrays the event.[
8 ] Similar to documentary evidence, circumstances or other factors could be used for authentication. Admissibility of a videotape was upheld even though no personal authentication was given at trial; instead, a supervisor of a store that was robbed testified that he was familiar with the video system of the store, that it was working on the day of the robbery, and that he personally removed the videotape and gave it to police for further investigation. The supervisor's testimony provided sufficient evidence of the video's reliability.[
9]

Motion picture film is admissible in evidence[10] and might require greater authentication to show there were no deletions or other technical manipulations in its production.[
11] For an appeal, a party could place a description of the scenes in the record and hold the film until needed. A party may include a description of the film scenes in an appellate record and retain the film until needed by the court.
Ga. Sup. Ct. R. 71 provides in part: “Where the admissibility of photographs is attacked, the originals or exact duplicates, to be furnished by appellant, shall be included in the transcript.”
Ga. Ct. of Appeals R. 21 provides for original evidence or exhibits to be transmitted to the appellate court on motion of a party explaining “the reason such original evidence or exhibits are necessary for the determination of the appeal.”
Still photographs that were time-stamped and dated and taken from a surveillance video were properly admitted where a witness testified that she was familiar with the surroundings and that the video accurately depicted the mall where the shooting took place, and a second witness that had watched the video testified the video accurately depicted what happened the day of the shooting.[
12]

Photographs are admissible into evidence when relevant and are often used to show an incident location or premises condition.[
13]

Georgia courts have admitted enlarged photographs,[14] posed photographs,[15] color photographs,[16] and aerial photographs.[
17]

Photographs of the deceased are admissible in homicide prosecutions or wrongful death actions.[
18]

In wrongful death actions, a party may show age, life expectancy, and earning capacity of the deceased so the photograph must be a correct likeness of the deceased at the time of death.[
19] Also, photographs of a corpse are admissible.[
20]

A few jurisdictions have excluded gruesome photographs that might inflame the jury when they added no fact not already before the jury.[
21] However, Georgia has specifically refused to follow such a rule, stating: “To exclude evidence of this character on the ground that it would inflame the minds of the jury, would prevent the State from establishing facts material to the issue. A relevant and material fact is not subject to an objection that it would inflame the minds of the jury.”
[ 22]

In Ramey v. State ,[23] the court expressed considerable concern about photographs taken during an autopsy, but stated: “We therefore adhere to the existing rule, which is: Photographs which are relevant to any issue in the case are admissible even though they may have an effect upon the jury.”

In Williams v. State ,[24] the Georgia Supreme Court found that four out of seven photographs were repetitious and that the autopsy photograph should not have been admitted, but that the error was not reversible. Subsequently, the court said, in Strickland v. State ,[25] “While we disapprove of introducing repetitious and cumulative photographs of the victims of crime,” the photographs here were not particularly gruesome and were relevant.
Later that year, in Brown v. State ,[26] the court established a rule regarding autopsy photographs:

We take this opportunity to announce a rule to assist counsel in the future in deciding what photos may be offered in evidence. A photograph which depicts the victim after autopsy incisions are made or after the state of the body is changed by authorities or the pathologist will not be admissible unless necessary to show some material fact which becomes apparent only because of the autopsy. A photograph which shows mutilation of a victim resulting from the crime against him may, however gruesome, have relevance to the trial of his alleged assailant. The necessary further mutilation of a body at autopsy has no such relevance and may cause confusion, if not prejudice, in the minds of jurors. Thus the admission of state's exhibit #5 in this case was reversible error.

In applying the rule, courts have held photographs admissible[27] and inadmissible.[
28]

Where the photograph is relevant to some material issue in the case, such as the cause of death, it is admissible.[
29]

It was not erroneous for the court to admit two photographs, depicting injuries to the victim's face suffered at or just before her murder, which aided the jury in determining whether defendant acted with malice aforethought.[
30]

Photographs obtained at a defendant's house, which showed nude women and bags containing a green leafy substance, were admissible in a prosecution for possession of marijuana.[
31] The court reasoned that the photographs were admissible because they associated the defendant with the crime for which he was charged.

Photographs showing the injury are admissible in an action for personal injuries.[
32]

Photographs of personal property such as a cigar box or a steer are also admissible.[
33]

Also, O.C.G.A. § 24-9-923(c) addresses the admissibility of photographs, motion pictures, pictures, and video and audio recordings made without the involvement of a human being, such as videotapes made by automatic security cameras. When a device produces these items at a time when the device producing the items was not being operated by a person, in the presence of a person or controlled by a person, they are admissible in evidence when the court determines that such items reliably represent the fact(s) for which the items are offered. The court should ensure, prior to admitting the evidence, that the date and time of the evidence is contained on the evidence and such date and time is contemporaneous with the events depicted in the photograph, videotape, or motion picture.

In Dawson v. State ,[34] the court held admissible a hotel surveillance videotape that contained images of the defendant with the victim in a trial for felony murder despite both the defendant and victim being unavailable to provide authentication. The cameras were not operated by person, under personal control, or in presence of individual operator, the date-time stamp was made contemporaneously with events depicted on the videotape, and the inaccuracy of the date-time stamp went to the weight of the evidence, not its admissibility. Likewise, video recordings on a surveillance video were held admissible even where the date stamp was erroneous, where the officer retrieving the film noted that the time stamp on the recording device was incorrect and determined the correct date and time.[
35] Recordings were also admissible where the victim testified as to the date of the event depicted on the recording, although the recording was not time-stamped.[
36] Thus, where the court can find that the recording accurately represents the facts for which it is offered, the court will allow the recording into evidence.

In Holloway v. State ,[37 ] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the evidence was sufficient to establish an adequate foundation for admission of surveillance videotape, although there was no testimony from the witness who observed events transpire contemporaneously with recording and the tape did not contain the date and time. In that case, a church custodian testified that he unlocked the box containing the tape in the presence of an officer who personally removed the tape and placed it into evidence. On the tape, the officer, who had known defendant for 19 years, observed footage from the day of the burglary showing defendant breaking a church window. Additionally, the technician who installed the security system watched the video and concluded that the camera had performed as it was designed to do.

In Sweatman v. State ,[38] a videotape of a statement by the victim had been properly authenticated. A videotape is, like a sound recording or photograph, a distinct recognizable physical object, and proof of chain of custody is not required.[
39]

Eiland v. State [40] is an unusual case in which the state offered a videotape made in daylight and showing a marked police car for a situation in which two unmarked police cars had attempted to stop the defendant's automobile around 11:30 p.m. The Georgia Court of Appeals held that the trial court erred in admitting a tape in which there were so many material variations and which was not necessary to the case.

In Pickrin v. State ,[41] the Georgia Supreme Court reaffirmed the right of lawyers to highlight and summarize their evidence during trial with illustrative tools like charts and videotaped reenactments. In that case, the court held that a party proffering a filmed reenactment must show that the tape accurately portrays the event in question, that it was filmed under conditions substantially similar to those existing at the time of the event, and “that the oral testimony will be inadequate to explain the … events depicted in the videotape.”
[42]

In Cleveland v. Bryant ,[43] the Georgia Court of Appeals upheld a computer-generated animation illustrating an expert's opinion about how a traffic wreck occurred because the trial court determined it was sufficiently similar to the evidence introduced at trial to admit it into evidence.

“Day in the life” films which demonstrate how catastrophic injuries and physical disabilities affect the daily lives of parties are admissible if they are not unnecessarily cumulative of the other evidence.[
44]

X-rays present a unique problem in that no witness can testify to seeing what the X-ray shows. Proper authentication here requires calling the person who took the X-ray as a witness to identify it.[
45] If this is not done, it is not properly authenticated.[
46] However, the Georgia Court of Appeals has held that an X-ray contained in medical records as a regular entry is admissible without other authentication.[
47]

A 1997 unreported personal injury case involving x-rays, Steiner v. Selph,[48] illustrates an unexpected evidentiary problem that can arise in the courtroom. During his deposition, the treating physician authenticated x-rays, which showed the plaintiff's injuries and the trial court admitted them into evidence. However, a problem arose when the physician's deposition was read to the jury because the deposition described the x-rays by number and the jury did not have the x-rays before them. The court ruled that the jurors could see the x-rays only if (1) the doctor came to court and read the transcript of his deposition to the jurors, or (2) the doctor gave live testimony at the trial. In practice, depositions taken for use as evidence are taken so witnesses will not have to come to court. Forcing witnesses to attend a trial and read the transcripts of their depositions is self-defeating. X-rays identified during a deposition “may be displayed to the jury while the deposition is being read.”
[49]
U.S. v. Hobbs, 403 F.2d 977 (6th Cir. 1968); Mikus v. U.S., 433 F.2d 719 (2d Cir. 1970).

O.C.G.A. § 24-1-104; Bradshaw v. State, 172 Ga. App. 330, 323 S.E.2d 253 (1984); McCormick on Evidence § 214 (6th ed.); Authentication or verification of photograph as basis for introduction in evidence, 9 A.L.R.2d 899; Admissibility of visual recording of event or matter giving rise to litigation or prosecution, 41 A.L.R.4th 812; Admissibility of visual recording of event or matter other than that giving rise to litigation or prosecution, 41 A.L.R.4th 877.

Coffee County v. Denton, 64 Ga. App. 368, 13 S.E.2d 209 (1941) (disapproved of on other grounds by, Sikes v. Candler County, 247 Ga. 115, 274 S.E.2d 464 (1981)); Sylvania Central Ry. Co. v. Gay, 82 Ga. App. 486, 61 S.E.2d 587 (1950).
In Harris v. Collins, 145 Ga. App. 827, 245 S.E.2d 13 (1978), the photograph was admissible since the change in circumstances was not substantial.
In Roberts v. State, 149 Ga. App. 667, 255 S.E.2d 126 (1979), photographs of the scene of a robbery taken in the daytime were properly admitted, although the robbery had taken place at night.
See Craft v. State, 154 Ga. App. 682, 269 S.E.2d 490 (1980).

Evans v. State, 70 Ga. App. 500, 28 S.E.2d 671 (1944); Stembridge v. State, 82 Ga. App. 214, 60 S.E.2d 491 (1950); Cagle Poultry & Egg Co. v. Busick, 110 Ga. App. 551, 139 S.E.2d 461 (1964); Turner v. State, 181 Ga. App. 531, 353 S.E.2d 13 (1987).
Beamon v. State, 348 Ga. App. 732, 824 S.E.2d 624 (2019).
Long v. General Elec. Co., 213 Ga. 809, 102 S.E.2d 9 (1958).
Thomas v. Fleming, 241 Miss. 26, 128 So. 2d 854 (1961).

O'Neal v. State, 213 Ga. 232, 98 S.E.2d 376 (1957); Georgia Power Co. v. Gillespie, 48 Ga. App. 688, 173 S.E. 755 (1934); Crittenden v. State, 98 Ga. App. 329, 105 S.E.2d 778 (1958); Grasham v. Southern Ry. Co., 111 Ga. App. 158, 141 S.E.2d 189 (1965); Smith v. Smith, 125 Ga. App. 257, 187 S.E.2d 330 (1972).

Epps v. State, 216 Ga. 606, 118 S.E.2d 574 (1961); Western & A.R.R. v. Reed, 35 Ga. App. 538, 134 S.E. 134 (1926); Kryder v. State, 75 Ga. App. 34, 41 S.E.2d 824 (1947); Jones v. State, 249 Ga. 605, 293 S.E.2d 708 (1982).

Butler v. State, 142 Ga. 286, 82 S.E. 654 (1914); Rose v. State, 184 Ga. 451, 191 S.E. 426 (1937); City Council of Augusta v. Lee, 153 Ga. App. 94, 264 S.E.2d 683 (1980) (posed motion pictures); Brown v. Barnes, 162 Ga. App. 383, 290 S.E.2d 483 (1982) (posed photograph of scene of accident taken a year after the accident held admissible without discussion).
Curtis v. State, 224 Ga. 870, 165 S.E.2d 150 (1968); Cagle Poultry & Egg Co. v. Busick, 110 Ga. App. 551, 139 S.E.2d 461 (1964).
Hubert v. City of Marietta, 224 Ga. 706, 164 S.E.2d 832 (1968); In Interest of J.S.S., 168 Ga. App. 340, 308 S.E.2d 855 (1983) (aerial photo); see Aaron v. State, 271 Ala. 70, 122 So. 2d 360 (1960).
Patterson v. State, 181 Ga. 698, 184 S.E. 309 (1936); City Ice Delivery Co. v. Turley, 44 Ga. App. 32, 160 S.E. 517 (1931); Richmond v. State, 124 Ga. App. 650, 185 S.E.2d 560 (1971).
Elliott v. Georgia Power Co., 58 Ga. App. 151, 197 S.E. 914 (1938); Trammell v. Matthews, 86 Ga. App. 661, 72 S.E.2d 132 (1952).
Beasley v. State, 239 Ga. 49, 235 S.E.2d 520 (1977); Johnson v. State, 239 Ga. 324, 236 S.E.2d 661 (1977).
State v. Waitus, 224 S.C. 12, 77 S.E.2d 256 (1953); State v. Jones, 228 S.C. 484, 91 S.E.2d 1 (1956) (overruled on other grounds by, State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991)).
For a good discussion and application of this rule, see State v. Clawson, 165 W. Va. 588, 270 S.E.2d 659 (1980).
Avery v. State, 209 Ga. 116, 126, 70 S.E.2d 716 (1952), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 345 U.S. 559, 73 S. Ct. 891, 97 L. Ed. 1244 (1953).

See Allen v. State, 231 Ga. 17, 200 S.E.2d 106 (1973); Dixon v. State, 231 Ga. 33, 200 S.E.2d 138 (1973).
Mize v. State, 240 Ga. 197, 240 S.E.2d 11 (1977); Moore v. State, 240 Ga. 807, 243 S.E.2d 1 (1978); Lister v. State, 143 Ga. App. 483, 238 S.E.2d 591 (1977).

There was some indication in Holcomb v. State, 130 Ga. App. 154, 202 S.E.2d 529 (1973), that where the photograph added nothing of probative value it should not be admitted. This case was disapproved as not correctly stating the law of Georgia in Stevens v. State, 242 Ga. 34, 247 S.E.2d 838 (1978), and Godfrey v. State, 243 Ga. 302, 253 S.E.2d 710 (1979), judgment rev'd in part on other grounds, 446 U.S. 420, 100 S. Ct. 1759, 64 L. Ed. 2d 398 (1980).

See Mooney v. State, 243 Ga. 373, 254 S.E.2d 337 (1979) (abrogated on other grounds by, Horton v. California, 496 U.S. 128, 110 S. Ct. 2301, 110 L. Ed. 2d 112 (1990)); Perkins v. State, 152 Ga. App. 101, 262 S.E.2d 158 (1979).

In Blankenship v. State, 247 Ga. 590, 277 S.E.2d 505 (1981) (overruled on other grounds by, Thompson v. State, 263 Ga. 23, 426 S.E.2d 895 (1993)), the court indicated that there might be “some very exceptional circumstances [not present in that case]” that might exclude such photographs.

In Jones v. State, 249 Ga. 605, 293 S.E.2d 708 (1982) , the court said: “We decline to adopt a rule which would allow the admission of photographs only when they prove facts which cannot be proved by testimony.”
If pre-autopsy photographs are relevant and material to any issue in the case, they are admissible even if they are duplicative and may inflame the jury.

Photographs showing the extent and nature of the victim's wounds are material and relevant. This is not altered by the fact that the cause of death may not be in dispute.
Roberts v. State, 282 Ga. 548, 651 S.E.2d 689 (2007); Smith v. State, 280 Ga. 490, 492, 629 S.E.2d 816 (2006).
Williams v. State, 250 Ga. 553, 300 S.E.2d 301 (1983).
Strickland v. State, 250 Ga. 624, 300 S.E.2d 156 (1983).

Post-incision autopsy photographs are admissible if they show some material fact that becomes apparent only due to the autopsy.
Lyons v. State, 282 Ga. 588, 652 S.E.2d 525 (2007) (overruled on other grounds by, Garza v. State, 284 Ga. 696, 670 S.E.2d 73 (2008)); Banks v. State, 281 Ga. 678, 680–681, 642 S.E.2d 679 (2007) .

Richards v. State, 251 Ga. 447, 306 S.E.2d 302 (1983); Lewis v. State, 253 Ga. 339, 320 S.E.2d 161 (1984); Smith v. State, 253 Ga. 536, 322 S.E.2d 492 (1984); Appleby v. State, 256 Ga. 304, 348 S.E.2d 630 (1986); Lewis v. State, 180 Ga. App. 369, 349 S.E.2d 257 (1986); Turner v. State, 181 Ga. App. 531, 353 S.E.2d 13 (1987).
Ellis v. State, 168 Ga. App. 757, 309 S.E.2d 924 (1983); McCullough v. State, 255 Ga. 672, 341 S.E.2d 706 (1986).
Sanders v. State, 251 Ga. 70, 303 S.E.2d 13 (1983); Mincey v. State, 251 Ga. 255, 304 S.E.2d 882 (1983); Brooks v. State, 258 Ga. 20, 365 S.E.2d 97 (1988).

Trial court did not err in admitting a photograph taken the day after a rape depicting victim's vagina and bloody underwear, despite defendant's objection that the photograph was unnecessary and inflammatory and did not show any injuries.
Smith v. State, 291 Ga. App. 545, 662 S.E.2d 323 (2008).
Massengale v. State, 264 Ga. 51, 441 S.E.2d 238 (1994).
Harvill v. State, 190 Ga. App. 353, 378 S.E.2d 917 (1989) (overruled on other grounds by, Thackston v. State, 303 Ga. App. 718, 694 S.E.2d 136 (2010)).
Pace v. Cochran, 144 Ga. 261, 86 S.E. 934 (1915); Cagle Poultry & Egg Co. v. Busick, 110 Ga. App. 551, 139 S.E.2d 461 (1964).
In Worrell v. Worrell, 242 Ga. 44, 247 S.E.2d 847 (1978), a divorce action, photographs of two children were admissible for the jury to consider on the issue of child support.
Whippler v. State, 218 Ga. 198, 126 S.E.2d 744 (1962) (cigar box); Brown v. State, 74 Ga. App. 98, 38 S.E.2d 871 (1946) (red steer); Nance v. State, 84 Ga. App. 777, 66 S.E.2d 273 (1951) (still).
Brannon v. State, 298 Ga. 601, 783 S.E.2d 642 (2016).
Birdsong v. Barnett, 334 Ga. App. 120, 778 S.E.2d 372 (2015).
Holloway v. State, 287 Ga. App. 655, 653 S.E.2d 95 (2007) .
Sweatman v. State, 181 Ga. App. 474, 352 S.E.2d 796 (1987).

Eiland v. State, 130 Ga. App. 428, 203 S.E.2d 619 (1973); Jones v. State, 250 Ga. 498, 299 S.E.2d 549 (1983) (videotape of scene of crime); Adams v. Southern Ry. Co., 180 Ga. App. 578, 349 S.E.2d 809 (1986).
See Sweatman v. State, 181 Ga. App. 474, 352 S.E.2d 796 (1987).

See also Pickren v. State, 269 Ga. 453, 500 S.E.2d 566 (1998), in which the Supreme Court emphasized that cumulative reenactment video based on State's theory of case is inadmissible in opening statement.
Pickren v. State, 269 Ga. 453, 500 S.E.2d 566 (1998).
Pickren v. State, 269 Ga. 453, 500 S.E.2d 566 (1998).
Cleveland v. Bryant, 236 Ga. App. 459, 460, 512 S.E.2d 360 (1999).
White v. Regions Bank, 275 Ga. 38, 561 S.E.2d 806 (2002) .
Lanier v. State, 50 Ga. App. 154, 177 S.E. 270 (1934).
See Painter v. State, 237 Ga. 30, 226 S.E.2d 578 (1976).
Williams v. Southern Ry. Co., 99 Ga. App. 503, 109 S.E.2d 343 (1959); Woodruff v. Naik, 181 Ga. App. 70, 351 S.E.2d 233 (1986) (error was harmless in this case).
Rouse v. Fussell, 106 Ga. App. 259, 126 S.E.2d 830 (1962).
Steiner v. Selph, DeKalb Superior Court, Civil Action Number 96-2167-8.
Trial Manual, 7-10, Georgia Trial Lawyers Association (1994).
